body_content.explanation: a series of musical notes, especially one that is pleasant and easy to remember:
examples: He was humming a tune as he dried the dishes.
That's a very catchy tune (= easy to remember and pleasant).

body_content.explanation: singing or playing notes that are at the right pitch (= level) or that agree with others being sung or played:
examples: She can't even sing in tune.

body_content.explanation: singing or playing notes that are at the wrong pitch (= level) or that do not agree with others being sung or played:
examples: The piano is out of tune.

body_content.explanation: If you are in tune with people or ideas, you understand or agree with them, and if you are out of tune with them, you do not:
examples: Much of his success comes from being in tune with what his customers want.
The City Council had financed the new building to the tune of over four million pounds.

body_content.explanation: to change a part of a musical instrument so that the instrument produces the correct sounds when played:
examples: Get into the habit of tuning your guitar every day before you practise.
She tuned (up) her violin before the concert.

body_content.explanation: to move the controls on a radio, television, etc. so that it receives programmes broadcast from a particular station:
examples: Press this button and the video will automatically tune itself to the next channel.
His radio is constantly tuned to KROQ-FM, the local rock station.

body_content.explanation: to make slight changes to an engine so that it works as well as possible:
examples: The engine needs tuning, but there's nothing wrong with the car.
Could you tune (up) the engine for me, please?
